Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns of calcined catalysts, (b) FT–IR patterns of calcined catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) H2–TPR profiles of calcined Ni/SiO2 catalysts, (b) XRD patterns of reduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 TEM images and particle size distributions (count > 150) of reduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by different methods. (a) Ni/SiO2-AE, (b) Ni/SiO2-DP, (c) Ni/SiO2-IM. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Characterizations of surface acidity properties. (a) NH3–TPD results of reduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts, (b) Py–FTIR spectra of reduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 XPS spectra of reduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalytic performance with optimal reaction conditions over Ni/SiO2-AE catalysts: (a) Reduction temperature, (b) Reaction temperature, (c) H2 pressure, (d) NH3/Alcohol ratio. General reaction conditions: 1.0 mmol octanol, 20 mL THF, 100 mg catalyst, 3 bar H2, T = 180 °C, t = 4 h, NH3/Alcohol = 11. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Catalytic performance of different catalysts over reaction time: (a) Ni/SiO2-AE, (b) Ni/SiO2-DP, (c) Ni/SiO2-IM catalysts. Reaction conditions: 1.0 mmol octanol, 20 mL THF, 100 mg catalyst, 3 bar H2, T = 180 °C, NH3/Alcohol = 11. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) The relationship between reaction time and octanol conversion, (b) The relationship between octanol conversion and octylamine selectivity, (c) A comparison of primary amine yield over the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst and representative Ni-based, non-precious, and precious metal catalysts. The data are listed in Supplementary Table S5. Reaction conditions: 1.0 mmol octanol, 20 mL THF, 100 mg catalyst, 3 bar H2, T = 180 °C, NH3/Alcohol = 11. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Recycle stability of Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst. Reaction conditions: 1.0 mmol octanol, 20 mL THF, 100 mg catalyst, 3 bar H2, T = 180 °C, t = 4 h, NH3/Alcohol = 11. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 (a) Catalytic performance of Ni/SiO2 catalysts in octanol dehydrogenation, (b) Correlation between TOF for octanol amination and dehydrogenation with S acid. Reaction conditions: 1.0 mmol octanol, 20 mL THF, 100 mg Catalyst, Ar = 10 bar, T = 180 °C, t = 4 h. Fig. 10 Scheme 1 Reductive amination pathway of alcohol to amine. Scheme 1 Table 1 Physicochemical properties of Ni/SiO2 catalysts. Nickel phyllosilicate derived metal–acid bifunctional Ni/SiO2 catalysts for selective reductive amination of alcohols Qiongjin Jiang Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Shiyi Rao Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Zhenyu Yang Investigation Data curation Xiao Fu Writing – original draft Investigation Weikun Chen Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Linmin Ye Writing – review & editing Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis ⁎ 1 Youzhu Yuan Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ 2 State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, China State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 China State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 0000–0003-0721–2287 2 0000–0003-1668–9984 The reductive amination of alcohols offers a cost-effective and sustainable pathway for the synthesis of amines. However, achieving high selectivity for primary amines remains a challenge. Herein, we report a nickel phyllosilicate catalyst (Ni/SiO2-AE) synthesized via ammonia evaporation, which demonstrates superior catalytic performance with 53.2% alcohol conversion and 96.2% primary amine selectivity. This outperforms conventional Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by impregnation (16.5% conversion, 98.6% selectivity) and deposition-precipitation (41.3% conversion, 94.5% selectivity). The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst exhibits remarkable stability over five reaction cycles, demonstrating both durability and recyclability. Characterization studies reveal that the high catalytic performance stems from the synergy between highly dispersed Ni0 nanoparticles and Lewis acid sites derived from unsaturated Ni(II) species, which facilitate alcohol adsorption and activation. Additionally, the robust skeletal structure of nickel phyllosilicate contributes to the recyclability of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst. The metal–acid bifunctional Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst also displays broad substrate applicability, effectively converting diverse alcohols into their corresponding primary amines. Graphical Abstract Keywords Reductive amination Ammonia evaporation method Nickel phyllosilicate Lewis acid sites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Amines represent a critically important class of chemical compounds, serving as pivotal building blocks and intermediates in the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and functional materials [1–6]. Driven by their simple structure, high chemical reactivity, and extensive potential for derivatization, primary amines have prompted researchers to develop environmentally efficient synthetic routes for their production. Consequently, a variety of synthetic methods for constructing primary amine compounds through catalytic functional group transformation using aqueous ammonia or other nitrogen sources has been established. For example, haloalkane amination involves simple substrates but is prone to over-alkylation and requires an acid scavenger [7,8]. Reduction hydrogenation of nitriles offers high atom economy yet necessitates noble-metal catalysts and harsh H2 conditions [9–12]. Hydroamination of alkenes enables atom-efficient C–N bond formation but is restricted to activated alkenes and is catalyst-sensitive [13]. Reductive amination of aldehydes/ketones achieves excellent selectivity but requires pre-synthesized carbonyl precursors [14,15]. Additionally, reductive amination of alcohols has been explored as a promising alternative [16,17]. Among these approaches, alcohols are widely available and relatively inexpensive compared to other reaction feedstocks. The reductive amination of alcohols with ammonia (NH3) produces water as the sole stoichiometric side product, emerging as an atom-economic and environmental-benign method to produce amines [16]. Typically, the reductive amination of alcohols with NH3 involves three key steps: dehydrogenation of the alcohol to form an aldehyde, condensation of the aldehyde with NH3 to yield an imine and water, and finally hydrogenation of the imine to produce an amine ( Scheme 1). Nevertheless, achieving high selectivity remains a significant challenge in this process. This challenge mainly arises from the high reactivity of alcohol substrates, as they tend to undergo further reactions, resulting in the formation of secondary and tertiary amines as by-products. Although heterogeneous catalysts have been introduced to enhance the reaction efficiency, they often suffer from low primary amine selectivity and the requirement for harsh reaction conditions. For instance, the reductive amination of methanol to MAs over H-rho catalyst at 450 °C achieved 87.7% conversion, but the selectivity of primary amine was only 31.3% [18]. The amination of biomass-derived alcohols over 5 wt% Ru/Al2O3 catalyst in aqueous ammonia solution yielded a primary amine of 38.4% [19]. As for the amination of dodecanol with NH3, increasing the H2 pressure from 0.2 to 10 bar significantly enhanced the selectivity to dodecylamine [20]. Current heterogeneous catalysts for the reductive amination of alcohols and NH3 primarily include supported Ru-based [21–23], Pd-based [24], Pt-based [25], Co-based [26,27], and Ni-based catalysts [6,28]. Among them, Ni-based catalysts have attracted considerable attention due to their cost-effectiveness and catalytic activity. Shimizu et al. [28] studied the activity of Ni catalysts supported on various oxides for the amination of octanol and found that Ni/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the best performance. Christopher et al. [29] prepared a Ni/HAP (hydroxyapatite) catalyst for the amination of 1-propanol, achieving a TOF of 1.7 s−1 under reaction conditions of 150 °C, which is far exceeding the performance of Ni catalysts supported on γ-Al2O3 and MgO. These studies demonstrate that the synergy between the basic sites of the support and the active Ni sites is crucial for enhancing reaction rates. In addition to the role of basic sites, acid sites also play a significant role. Cho et al. [30] and Li et al. [31] investigated the roles of acid sites in amine synthesis using different Ni-supported catalysts. They found that the density of Lewis acid sites in Ni/Al2O3 catalysts correlates positively with the selectivity for monoisopropylamine, while the Ni/ZrO2 catalyst demonstrates high reducibility and surface acid density, enhancing both activity and selectivity in the amination of 2-hydroxytetrahydropyran. Our group previously reported a layered nickel phyllosilicate catalyst with exceptional catalytic performance and stability, particularly in the hydrogenation of naphthalene [32]. Studies revealed that the synergistic effects of Lewis acid sites and tailored pore size are critical to its catalytic activity. Similarly, Kong et al. [33] embedded Ni nanoparticles into a layered nickel phyllosilicate framework to develop a metal–acid bifunctional catalyst, which exhibited remarkable activity in the low-temperature hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural. Reduction treatments yielded highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles, while unreduced Ni(II) species forms coordinatively unsaturated Lewis acid sites. This synergistic interaction significantly enhances catalytic performance. In this study, we report a nickel phyllosilicate catalyst (Ni/SiO2-AE) prepared by ammonia evaporation method for the reductive amination of alcohols to primary amines. These results notably surpass those of Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by impregnation and deposition-precipitation methods (Ni/SiO2-IM and Ni/SiO2-DP). Through comprehensive characterizations, we elucidate the structure-performance relationship of the nickel phyllosilicate catalyst, highlighting the critical role of the synergistic interaction between metal and acid sites in achieving superior catalytic performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst was prepared by a modified ammonia evaporation procedure [33–35]. Typically, 2.5 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was added to ammonia aqueous solution (10 mL of deionized water and 6.0 mL of 25 wt% ammonia aqueous solution) and stirred for 0.5 h. Subsequently, 5.0 g of silica sol (40 wt%) was added to the solution and stirred for 8 h at room temperature. Following this, the suspension was heated in a water bath preheated to 80 °C to evaporate NH3 until the pH of the suspension decreased to 7. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was filtered, washed with deionized water, and dried at 100 °C overnight. Finally, the sample calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in air. Ni/SiO2-DP catalyst was prepared by deposition-precipitation method [36]. 2.5 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water, and this solution was then dropwise added to 2.0 g of SiO2 (The support SiO2 for impregnation was obtained by drying silica sol at 80 °C), followed by stirring for 0.5 h. Subsequently, a 0.5 mol L−1 Na2CO3 was introduced to the mixture until the pH reached 7, after which stirring was continued for an additional 2 h. The subsequent steps of filtration, washing, drying, and calcination were carried out with the same steps as those used in the preparation process of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst. Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst was prepared by impregnation method. 2.5 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water, and this solution was then dropwise added to 2.0 g of SiO2, followed by stirring for 12 h. The drying and calcination steps were identical to those used in the preparation process of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected using a Rigaku MiniFlex Ⅱ diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (30 kV, 15 mA), operated at a scan speed of 10° min−1. Physical absorptions of the samples were carried out on a Micromeritics TriStar 3000 equipment. The samples were pre-degassed at 150 °C under high vacuum for 3 h to remove the adsorbed surface organics. Then, argon gas was used as the adsorbent for testing. The specific surface area (S BET) was determined through the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method on the basis of the data points of relative pressure (P/P0). The pore diameters of the Ni/SiO2 catalysts were estimated according to the Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) model. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on a TECNAI F30 transmission electron microscope. The samples were dispersed in ethanol and then dropped onto a Cu grid before measurement. The metal contents of the catalysts were obtained with a BRUKER XRF spectrometer operated at 60 kV and 50 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed using a Qtac-100 LEISS spectrometer with a 300 W monochromatic Al Kα radiation source. The binding energies of the catalysts were corrected according to the C1s peak at 284.6 eV. FT–IR spectroscopy was measured on a Nicolet 6700 facility. Before testing, the sample was mixed and ground with potassium bromide in a ratio of 1:100, and then pressed into a 13 mm disc. A resolution of 4 cm−1 and 36 scans were applied for all the experiments. Before the measurement, reduced catalyst was pretreated under 5% H2/Ar atmosphere at 650 °C for 3 h. Pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py–FTIR) was conducted on a Bruker TENSOR 27 spectrometer. The reduced samples were degassed at 300 °C in vacuum. Subsequently, it was exposed to pyridine vapor at 35 °C for 30 min. The Py–FTIR spectral data were recorded after evacuating for 1 h at 150 °C. TPD and TPR were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem Ⅱ 2920 instrument by using a mass spectrometer to detect the target signal. H2–TPR was conducted under a 5% H2/Ar atmosphere. Before testing, sample was pretreated under argon at 200 °C for 1 h. Then the gas was changed to 5% H2/Ar for TPR with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1. When operating NH3–TPD, the sample was pretreated with 5% H2/Ar for 3 h under 650 °C, switching to argon and purging for 30 min after the temperature was reduced to 50 °C. After that, the adsorption of NH3 was conducted for 1 h and changed to argon flow for 2 h to remove the physical adsorption of NH3. Heating process began after the above had been completed and the heating rate was maintained at 10 °C min−1. For H2–TPD test, the pre-treatment procedure remained the same as NH3–TPD, changing the probe molecule to hydrogen and pre-adsorption with it for 2 h, and the subsequent procedure remained the same but the highest desorption temperature at 400 °C. For the samples used in characterization, the XRD patterns of the calcined catalyst were directly measured. The XRD patterns and TEM images of the catalyst after reaction were obtained immediately after vacuum drying. For all other measurements, the samples were reduced and stored in a dry container filled with N2 to prevent oxidation before testing. In the related characterizations, these samples were labeled as “calcined Ni/SiO2 catalyst”, “spent Ni/SiO2 catalyst”, and “reduced Ni/SiO2 catalyst”, respectively. 2.3 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic performance was evaluated in a 100 mL Parr steel autoclave. Typically, 1.0 mmol octanol, 20 mL of Tetrahydrofuran (THF), 0.5 mmol of dodecane (internal standard) and 100 mg of catalyst were added in the reactor. After sealing and purging with pure N2 thrice, the reactor was charged with NH3 and H2 at the specified pressures. Subsequently, the reactor was heated to a specified temperature and maintained for 4 h. The influence of internal and external diffusion was examined by changing the size of the catalyst and the stirring speed. As shown in Tables S1 and S2, the mass transport limitations were effectively eliminated under the reaction conditions used (800 rpm, 150 mesh). Therefore, all experiments were carried out under reaction-controlled conditions. After cooling and decompressing, the liquid products were analyzed using Agilent 7890 gas chromatography (GC) equipped with a DM-35 Amine column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 1 μm) and a flame ionization detector. The initial oven temperature was kept at 50 °C for 7 min, and this temperature was increased to 200 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C min−1, and then maintained for 3 min. The conversion of octanol, octylamine selectivity, and TOF were calculated using Eqs. (1), (2), and (3), respectively. (1) O ctanol c onversion ( % ) = Moles of octanol converted Total moles of octanol × 100 % (2) Octylamine s electivity ( % ) = Moles of octylamine produced Moles of octanol converted × 100 % (3) TOF = Moles of octanol converted Moles of surface nickel atoms × reaction time Where, moles of surface nickel atoms were determined by {number of surface Ni atoms per 10–19 m2 (1.54 × 1019) × nickel surface area × mass of catalyst / Avogadro constant N A }. For the catalyst recycling experiment, the catalyst was collected by filtration after the reaction and washed three times with deionized water and ethanol. Then the catalyst was ready to reuse in the next run. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ni/SiO 2 Catalysts XRD measurement was conducted to characterize the crystalline structure of catalysts. As shown in Fig. S1, the broad XRD peaks at 33.7° and 60.9° of Ni/SiO2-AE and Ni/SiO2-DP precursors are attributed to nickel phyllosilicate (PDF#43–0664) [33,35]. After calcination at 600 °C for 4 h, the characteristic diffraction peaks of nickel phyllosilicate are still observed in the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst ( Fig. 1a), indicating that the catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method exhibits excellent thermal stability. The Ni/SiO2-DP and Ni/SiO2-IM catalysts exhibit diffraction peaks at 37.2° and 43.2°, which are assigned to NiO (PDF#44–1159). The formation of phyllosilicate was also verified by FT–IR (Fig. 1b). The adsorption peaks located at approximately 670, 1024, and 3627 cm−1 are attributed to δ OH vibration, symmetric in-plane Si–O vibration, and ν OH stretching of nickel phyllosilicate [33,34,37], respectively. The result suggests that the calcined Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst retains its skeletal structure in nickel phyllosilicate form, which is consistent with the XRD pattern. The H2–TPR revealed the reduction behavior of Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by different methods ( Fig. 2a). Ni/SiO2-DP and Ni/SiO2-IM catalysts both exhibit a reduction peak at 270–450 °C, which is attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO with weak interactions [38]. In addition, a high-temperature reduction peak centered at 554 °C is assigned to the reduction of larger NiO nanoparticles. Compared to the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst, the Ni/SiO2-DP catalyst exhibits an additional high-temperature reduction peak at 645 °C, which is associated with the reduction of a small amount of 1:1 nickel phyllosilicate [39]. The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst shows the main reduction peaks in high temperature region above 700 °C caused by the reduction of Ni–O–Si bonds in 2:1 nickel phyllosilicate species [40]. Due to the strong metal-support interaction, nickel phyllosilicate requires higher temperature to be reduced. The XRD patterns of the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst in Fig. 2b exhibit diffraction peaks at 44.6°, 51.8°, and 76.4°, which can be attributed to the (111), (200), and (220) planes of metallic Ni (PDF#87–0712). These sharp diffraction peaks in the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst indicated its Ni nanoparticle size is significantly larger than those of the Ni/SiO2-AE and Ni/SiO2-DP catalysts. It is worth mentioning that the diffraction peaks attributed to nickel phyllosilicate of Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst still can be observed after reduction. TEM was employed to ascertain the distribution of metallic Ni. The particle size distribution histograms in Fig. 3 indicate that the Ni/SiO2-AE and Ni/SiO2-DP catalysts have average sizes of 4.6 nm and 5.6 nm, respectively, while the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst has a significantly larger average size of 19.4 nm ( Table 1). Additionally, the characteristic “fibrous” microstructures of the nickel phyllosilicate phase is observed after reduction over Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst (Fig. 3a) [35], which is consistent with the XRD and TPR results. Based on the particle size, the metal dispersion of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst is 0.22 (Table 1), which is significantly higher than that of the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst (0.05). It is evident that Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst synthesized by ammonia evaporation method has the fibrous phyllosilicate structure, which can limit the agglomeration of Ni species and form highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles during the reduction process. The N2 adsorption−desorption isotherms of Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst are shown in Fig. S2. According to the IUPAC classification, the profiles display a type IV isotherm shape. The Ni/SiO2-DP and Ni/SiO2-IM catalysts exhibit a typical H1 hysteresis behavior, which is the characteristic feature of the mesoporous materials with a relatively concentrated pore size distribution and uniform spherical particles [41]. Notably, the shape of the hysteresis loop in Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst is type H3 caused by the formation of fibrous nickel phyllosilicate, matching the morphological features of the catalyst as shown by TEM. The fibrous structure also promotes the increase of BET surface area (Table 1). The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst possesses a higher specific surface area (248 m2 g−1) than the other two catalysts due to the existence of layered nickel phyllosilicate structures. The surface acidity of the reduced catalysts was investigated using NH3–TPD ( Fig. 4a). For all catalysts, the desorption peaks are observed around 200 °C corresponded to weak acid sites, while peaks between 200 °C and 400 °C indicate the existence of moderately-strong acid sites. The Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst shows minimal NH3 desorption peaks due to the slight acidity of the SiO2 support. In contrast, the Ni/SiO2-AE and Ni/SiO2-DP catalysts display pronounced NH3 desorption peaks, with Ni/SiO2-AE exhibiting the largest peak area, indicating a higher density of acid sites. The acid amounts of the catalysts determined according to NH3–TPD are summarized in Table 1. To further investigate the nature of the acid sites, we performed the pyridine adsorbed FTIR (Py–FTIR) spectra (Fig. 4b). The strong bands at 1449 cm−1, 1610 cm−1 and a small band at 1490 cm−1 are consistent with the adsorption of pyridine on Lewis acid sites [42]. The quantity of surface acid sites is related to the structure of nickel phyllosilicate, where the Lewis acid sites originate from coordinatively unsaturated Ni(II) sites, resulting from the broken bonds near the edges and surfaces of the nickel phyllosilicate [43]. XPS characterization was employed to further elucidate the nickel species on the surface of the Ni/SiO2 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5, the Ni2+ species in the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst correspond to nickel phyllosilicate, with a binding energy at 856.6 eV [33]. In contrast, the Ni2+ species in the Ni/SiO2-DP and Ni/SiO2-IM catalysts are associated with NiO, with binding energies around 855.8 eV [44]. The Ni0 content in the reduced Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst is the lowest at 32.8% (Table S3), indicating the difficult reducibility of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst with a significant amount of nickel phyllosilicate structure, which is beneficial to maintain Ni nanoparticle size during reaction. 3.2 Catalytic Performance The catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts was investigated and compared in the reductive amination of octanol with NH3 and H2. Table 2 shows that the unreduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts are inactive, with no detectable products. Raney Ni, a metal-only industrial catalyst, lacks surface acidic sites for NH3 adsorption [45], which limits aldimine condensation and results in primary amine selectivity of 85.7%. Ni/γ-Al2O3 has abundant surface acidic sites that promote aldimine condensation to form primary amine. However, the weak interactions between its surface Ni0 and the Al2O3 support cause primary amine to couple into secondary amine [46]. The reduced Ni/SiO2 catalysts exhibit higher primary amine selectivity and different octanol conversion compared to these catalysts. Notably, the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst achieves a conversion of 53.2% for octanol and a selectivity of 96.2% for octylamine after 4 h of reaction. Additionally, the TOF values calculated at low conversion reveal that the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst (21.1 h−1) outperforms the Ni/SiO2-DP catalyst (14.0 h−1) and the Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst (6.0 h−1). These results suggest that the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst demonstrates superior catalytic performance. This performance advantage is attributed to the presence of an optimal amount of metallic Ni0, which effectively promotes both alcohol dehydrogenation and imine hydrogenation in the reductive amination of octanol [47]. To achieve better catalytic performance and elucidate the reaction mechanisms, the reaction conditions for various catalysts were optimized in detail. Fig. 6a illustrates the effect of reduction temperature on the performance of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst. When the reduction temperature increases from 550 °C to 850 °C, the octanol conversion exhibits a “volcano-shaped” trend, peaking at 53.2% at a reduction temperature of 650 °C. Meanwhile, the octylamine selectivity remains consistently high, exceeding 96.0%. The physicochemical properties of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst reduced at different temperatures are illustrated in Table S4 and Fig. S3. Nickel phyllosilicate is difficult to reduce under 550 °C, resulting in a low portion of metallic Ni nanoparticle with an average size of 3.0 nm, as determined by XRD. The low surface Ni0 content of 11.4% leads to fewer active sites for octanol dehydration and a low conversion of 20.3%. As the reduction temperature increased from 650 °C to 850 °C, the conversion exhibits a volcano-type trend, decreasing from 53.2% to 39.9%. In this case, the Ni particle size slightly increased from 4.7 nm to 5.9 nm, while the surface Ni0 content rose significantly from 32.8% to 67.4%. Notably, the surface acid density (S acid) decreases rapidly as the reduction temperature increases. Higher reduction temperatures provide more Ni0 sites for octanol conversion but also reduce the amount of Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface, which slows down the condensation of octanal and NH3. Therefore, the balance between the amount of Ni0 and S acid is a key factor in achieving good catalytic performance in the reductive amination of alcohols to amines. This finding suggests that the synergistic effect of metal–acid bifunctional sites promotes the catalytic performance. With the reaction temperature ranging from 140 °C to 200 °C (Fig. 6b), an increase in reaction temperature enhances octanol conversion, though selectivity toward octylamine decreases due to an increase in the byproduct, dioctylamine. Notably, when the reaction temperature further rises to 180 °C, the octanol conversion shows a marked increase while maintaining high selectivity for octylamine (96.2%). The presence of a small amount of H2 (3 bar) facilitates imine hydrogenation to form the amine, thereby driving the overall reaction (Fig. 6c). However, excess H2 occupies a greater number of Ni0 active sites, affecting the adsorption and dehydrogenation of octanol, accelerating imine hydrogenation, and promoting further amination of octylamine, which reduces octylamine selectivity. As the NH3 to alcohol ratio increases, a slight decrease in octanol conversion is observed, but octylamine selectivity rises from 83.2% to 96.3% (Fig. 6d). Considering both conversion and selectivity, an optimal NH3 to alcohol ratio of 11 is selected for further studies, yielded a conversion of 53.2% and a selectivity of 96.2%. These experimental results align with previous reports, which indicate that increasing NH3 can suppress the formation of secondary amine [48]. Excess NH3 facilitates the condensation with aldehydes to form primary imine intermediates, which are then hydrogenated to primary amines, thereby enhancing the selectivity of primary amines. Additionally, a high NH3 concentration promotes trans-imination reactions, which convert by-products such as secondary imine back to primary imine intermediates, thus suppressing the formation of secondary amines [49]. As the reaction time increases, the octanol conversion for all catalysts exhibits a continuous upward trend ( Figs. 7 and 8a). The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst demonstrates higher conversion within a shorter time. Concurrently, the selectivity for octylamine decreases progressively due to the self-coupling of primary amine and the hydrogenation of secondary imine to form secondary amine. The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst prepared by the ammonia evaporation method exhibits a significant influence on the selectivity to octylamine at higher octanol conversion. At the same octanol conversion, it maintains a higher selectivity to octylamine compared to other catalysts (Fig. 8b). Fig. 8c presents a comparison of primary amine yield over the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst and representative Ni-based, non-precious, and precious metal catalysts. Among the precious metal catalysts, the small-sized Ru NP catalyst shows inhibited secondary imine hydrogenation, effectively restricting amine self-coupling, and achieves a high primary amine yield of 80.1% after 24 h of reaction (Table S5). The non-precious metal USY@Ni-3 catalyst delivers a 69.9% yield after 16 h of reaction. This reasonable performance is closely related to the numerous highly dispersed metallic Ni active sites and sufficient basic sites of the Al2O3 matrix, which are derived from the unique structure of NiAl-LDHs. In contrast, the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst, a non-precious metal catalyst, attains a primary amine yield of 68.6% within 8 h, surpassing most Ni-based and noble metal catalysts. The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst demonstrates superior performance in this process, as its surface Ni0 nanoparticles and Lewis acid sites synergistically facilitate the selective reduction of octanol to primary amine. 3.3 Stability of Ni/SiO 2 -AE catalyst Fig. 9 highlights the catalytic stability of Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst, which was evaluated at a middle conversion in order to reflect its real stability. The octanol conversion remains stable at approximately 53.0%, with more than 96.0% selectivity to octylamine for the fifth run. The XRD patterns (Fig. S4) indicate no significant changes in the diffraction peaks between fresh and spent Ni/SiO2-AE catalysts after five cycles, suggesting that the structure of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst remains stable during the reaction. In the TEM images (Fig. S5) of the used Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst, no obvious sintering of Ni nanoparticles is observed, with the Ni0 nanoparticle size only slightly increasing from 4.6 nm to 4.8 nm. The layered structure enhances the dispersion of Ni nanoparticles and establishes a robust metal-support interaction (SMSI) via Ni–O–Si bonds, thereby stabilizing the Ni nanoparticles during reactions and inhibiting their sintering [32]. Additionally, the observation of fibrous nickel phyllosilicate structures suggests that these structures maintain their integrity and stability on the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst even after multiple reaction cycles. 3.4 Substrate scope The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst was further applied to the reductive amination of various types of alcohols under optimized reaction conditions. As shown in Table S6, the catalyst efficiently catalyzes the reductive amination of primary, secondary, cyclic, and aromatic alcohols, achieving primary amine selectivity of over 95.0% in all cases presented. Specifically, benzyl alcohol achieves a conversion of 62.0% with benzylamine as the sole product and a selectivity of 100%. These results demonstrate that the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst exhibits potential applications in the reductive amination of alcohols. 3.5 Research on the structure-performance correlation To verify that alcohol dehydrogenation is the rate-determining step in the catalytic reductive amination of alcohols [50,51], we conducted experiments on the dehydrogenation of octanol to octanal over Ni/SiO2 catalysts. The Ni/SiO2-IM catalyst exhibits the lowest conversion of octanol, approximately 2.0%, while the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst shows the highest conversion, nearly 8.0% ( Fig. 10a). Under identical reaction conditions, the catalytic performance of the three catalysts in the dehydrogenation of octanol is consistent with their performance in the reductive amination of octanol. Therefore, these results provide additional evidence that alcohol dehydrogenation is the rate-determining step in the reductive amination of octanol. Fig. 10b illustrates a positive correlation between the TOF for both octanol amination and dehydrogenation with the surface acidity of the catalysts. The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst exhibits the highest surface acidity (2.81 μmol g−1), with corresponding TOF for octanol dehydrogenation and octanol amination reaching 2.1 h−1 and 21.1 h−1, respectively. It is speculated that the Lewis acid sites of the catalyst not only facilitate the activation of the carbonyl group, promoting the condensation and dehydration of aldehyde and amine to form an imine [52,53], but also favor the adsorption and activation of octanol, promoting the dehydrogenation of octanol to octanal [54,55]. Based on the catalytic performance and characterization results, it is proposed that the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst possesses highly dispersed metallic Ni0 active sites and a high concentration of Lewis acid sites. During the reductive amination of alcohols, the Ni0 sites govern the dehydrogenation of alcohols to aldehydes. Meanwhile, the Lewis acid sites enhance the adsorption of NH3 and facilitate its condensation with aldehydes to form imines. Subsequently, the imines are hydrogenated on the surface of Ni0 nanoparticles to produce primary amines [33,56]. Therefore, the Ni0 nanoparticles and Lewis acid sites work synergistically to catalyze the reductive amination of alcohols. 4 Conclusion In summary, a comparative study of Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by ammonia evaporation, deposition-precipitation and impregnation methods has been investigated for the reductive amination reactions. The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst derived from nickel phyllosilicate structure via ammonia evaporation method shows superior performance compared to the other two catalysts, with an octanol conversion of 53.2% and octylamine selectivity of 96.2% in 5 recycles under optimal reaction conditions. In addition, the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst also exhibits the potential applications in the reductive amination of other alcohols. Characterizations results indicate that the reduction process at 650 °C can generate highly dispersed Ni0 particles and abundant Lewis acid sites due to coordinatively unsaturated Ni (II) species, which are located in skeletal nickel phyllosilicate structure. The excellent performance of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst is attributed to the synergistic effect between highly dispersed Ni0 nanoparticles and Lewis acid sites. The Ni0 and Lewis acid sites are responsible to the enhancement of alcohol dehydrogenation and NH3 adsorption process, respectively, by which accelerates the reductive amination of alcohols to primary amines. coredata.dc:description: The reductive amination of alcohols offers a cost-effective and sustainable pathway for the synthesis of amines. However, achieving high selectivity for primary amines remains a challenge. Herein, we report a nickel phyllosilicate catalyst (Ni/SiO2-AE) synthesized via ammonia evaporation, which demonstrates superior catalytic performance with 53.2% alcohol conversion and 96.2% primary amine selectivity. This outperforms conventional Ni/SiO2 catalysts prepared by impregnation (16.5% conversion, 98.6% selectivity) and deposition-precipitation (41.3% conversion, 94.5% selectivity). The Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst exhibits remarkable stability over five reaction cycles, demonstrating both durability and recyclability. Characterization studies reveal that the high catalytic performance stems from the synergy between highly dispersed Ni0 nanoparticles and Lewis acid sites derived from unsaturated Ni(II) species, which facilitate alcohol adsorption and activation. Additionally, the robust skeletal structure of nickel phyllosilicate contributes to the recyclability of the Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst. The metal–acid bifunctional Ni/SiO2-AE catalyst also displays broad substrate applicability, effectively converting diverse alcohols into their corresponding primary amines.
